title: Isaiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 21.

questions.question: What is described as the 'burden of the desert of the sea' in Isaiah 21:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Whirlwinds in the south
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:1 describes the burden of the desert of the sea as whirlwinds in the south passing through.

questions.question: Who are called to besiege in Isaiah 21:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Elam and Media
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:2 calls Elam to go up and Media to besiege.

questions.question: What feeling did Isaiah describe in Isaiah 21:3 when he heard the vision?
options: Pain like a woman in labor
questions.correctAnswer: Pain like a woman in labor
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:3 states that Isaiah's loins were filled with pain, like the pangs of a woman in labor.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 21:4, what happened to the 'night of my pleasure'?
options: It became a time of rest
questions.correctAnswer: It was turned into fear
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:4 says the night of pleasure was turned into fear.

questions.question: What does Isaiah tell the princes to do in Isaiah 21:5?
options: Prepare the table, watch in the watchtower, eat, drink, and anoint the shield
Build a wall around the city
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare the table, watch in the watchtower, eat, drink, and anoint the shield
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:5 instructs the princes to prepare the table, watch, eat, drink, and anoint the shield.

questions.question: In Isaiah 21:6, what command does the Lord give regarding a watchman?
options: Go, set a watchman to declare what he sees
questions.correctAnswer: Go, set a watchman to declare what he sees
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:6 records the Lord's command to set a watchman to declare what he sees.

questions.question: What did the watchman see according to Isaiah 21:7?
options: A chariot with horsemen, asses, and camels
questions.correctAnswer: A chariot with horsemen, asses, and camels
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:7 describes the watchman seeing a chariot with horsemen, asses, and camels.

questions.question: What did the watchman cry out as recorded in Isaiah 21:8?
questions.correctAnswer: A lion
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:8 shows the watchman crying out, 'A lion'.

questions.question: What message did the watchman give about Babylon in Isaiah 21:9?
options: Babylon is fallen and her gods are broken
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon is fallen and her gods are broken
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:9 reports the watchman declaring that Babylon is fallen and all her gods' images are broken.

questions.question: What is the burden mentioned in Isaiah 21:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The burden of Dumah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:11 specifically refers to the burden of Dumah.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 21:12, the watchman said, 'The morning cometh, and also the night.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:12 records the watchman saying, 'The morning cometh, and also the night.'

questions.question: True or False: In Isaiah 21:13, the burden is upon Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:13 states the burden is upon Arabia, not Egypt.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 21:16 says all the glory of Kedar shall fail within a year.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:16 prophesies that within a year all the glory of Kedar shall fail.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Isaiah 21:14: 'The inhabitants of the land of Tema brought ______ to him that was thirsty.'
questions.correctAnswer: water
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:14 states that the inhabitants of Tema brought water to the thirsty.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Isaiah 21:15: 'They fled from the swords, from the drawn sword, and from the bent ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: bow
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:15 mentions fleeing from the bent bow.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is overwhelmed by fear and anxiety about the future. Based on Isaiah 21:3-4, what biblical truth would you share about dealing with such emotions?
options: Trust God even when your heart pants and you feel dismayed
Avoid thinking about troubling news to keep peace
Rely solely on your own strength to overcome fear
Ignore emotions because they are unspiritual
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God even when your heart pants and you feel dismayed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:3-4 shows the prophet's honest experience of pain and fear but sets the stage for trusting God's word despite these feelings. This teaches believers to acknowledge their emotions yet place trust in God amid trials (Isaiah 21:3-4, Isaiah 21:6, Isaiah 21:17).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 21:6-7 illustrate the importance of spiritual vigilance and preparedness in the Christian life?
options: Setting a watchman to declare what he sees symbolizes spiritual alertness
Ignoring warnings until the crisis arrives
Focusing only on physical safety measures
Waiting passively for events to unfold
questions.correctAnswer: Setting a watchman to declare what he sees symbolizes spiritual alertness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:6-7 describes God commanding a watchman to be alert and report what he observes. This reflects the need for believers to be spiritually watchful, prepared, and ready to share warnings or encouragement (Isaiah 21:6-7, Isaiah 21:8, Isaiah 21:9).

questions.question: When a believer faces the news of hardship or loss, such as 'Babylon is fallen' in Isaiah 21:9, how can this passage encourage them in terms of faith and hope?
options: Trust that God ultimately controls history and breaks down false powers
Focus only on worldly powers and worry about their downfall
Give up because all is lost
Ignore God's sovereignty in difficult times
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God ultimately controls history and breaks down false powers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:9 declares the fall of Babylon and breaking of idols, showing God's sovereignty over nations. Believers can find hope knowing God judges injustice and will bring restoration (Isaiah 21:9-10, Isaiah 21:17, Isaiah 21:2).

questions.question: A Christian struggling with patience in waiting on God’s timing might learn what from Isaiah 21:12 about perseverance?
options: The watchman says the morning comes even though night endures, teaching perseverance
Stop hoping because the night never ends
Abandon faith during periods of waiting
questions.correctAnswer: The watchman says the morning comes even though night endures, teaching perseverance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:12 records the watchman encouraging inquiry despite night still being present, reassuring that morning will come. This teaches believers perseverance and hope through dark times (Isaiah 21:11-12, Isaiah 21:4, Isaiah 21:17).

questions.question: In Isaiah 21:5, the princes are told to prepare the table and anoint the shield. How might this symbolize practical spiritual preparation and stewardship in the Christian life?
options: Preparing and anointing symbolize readiness and stewardship of God’s gifts
It means only physical preparation matters
questions.correctAnswer: Preparing and anointing symbolize readiness and stewardship of God’s gifts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:5 instructs leaders to prepare food and anoint shields, symbolizing readiness for battle and wise stewardship. Spiritually, believers are to prepare their hearts and lives for service and trials (Isaiah 21:5, Isaiah 21:6, Isaiah 21:17).

questions.question: How can the imagery of the watchman standing day and night in Isaiah 21:8 encourage believers about spiritual discipline?
options: Be consistently watchful in prayer and obedience, day and night
Rely on others to watch over you
questions.correctAnswer: Be consistently watchful in prayer and obedience, day and night
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:8 describes the watchman standing continually, symbolizing ongoing spiritual vigilance, prayer, and obedience. This encourages believers to maintain persistent spiritual discipline (Isaiah 21:6-8, Isaiah 21:12).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 21:2, how does God's word challenge believers to respond to treachery and injustice in daily life?
options: Recognize treachery but trust God to bring justice
Participate in treachery to get ahead
Take vengeance into your own hands
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize treachery but trust God to bring justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:2 describes treacherous dealers and spoilers but also declares God’s action to cease their sighing. Believers are called to trust God’s justice rather than resort to injustice themselves (Isaiah 21:2, Isaiah 21:17, Isaiah 21:9).

questions.question: What lesson about evangelism and sharing God’s message can be drawn from Isaiah 21:10 where the speaker declares what he heard from the LORD?
options: Be faithful to declare God’s word to others, even difficult news
Modify God’s word to suit others
questions.correctAnswer: Be faithful to declare God’s word to others, even difficult news
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:10 shows the prophet faithfully declaring the word he heard from God. This teaches believers the importance of boldly sharing God’s truth, regardless of difficulty (Isaiah 21:10, Isaiah 21:6-7, Isaiah 21:9).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 21:14-15 teaches that generosity and hospitality towards those fleeing danger is a biblical virtue.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:14-15 describes how inhabitants brought water and bread to the thirsty and fleeing, demonstrating biblical virtues of generosity and hospitality to those in need.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 21:16-17 reminds believers that God’s promises include the diminishing of the proud and mighty, encouraging humility.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:16-17 foretells the failure of Kedar’s glory and diminishing of mighty men by God’s decree, underscoring that reliance on human strength is futile and encouraging humility before God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with discouragement amid ongoing trials. How does Isaiah 21:11-12 teach perseverance and hope through the metaphor of the watchman?
options: The watchman’s answer that morning will come encourages hopeful endurance
The watchman advises giving up during the night
questions.correctAnswer: The watchman’s answer that morning will come encourages hopeful endurance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:11-12 shows a watchman asked about the night’s outcome, replying that morning comes, teaching believers to endure trials with hope and patience (Isaiah 21:11-12, Isaiah 21:4, Isaiah 21:17).

questions.question: How does the description of various chariots and horsemen in Isaiah 21:7 symbolize the need for discernment and attentiveness in spiritual life?
options: The watchman hearkened diligently, showing spiritual attentiveness is vital
Ignore signs and focus on comfort
Rely only on feelings, not observation
questions.correctAnswer: The watchman hearkened diligently, showing spiritual attentiveness is vital
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:7 describes the watchman listening carefully to different chariots, symbolizing the need for believers to be attentive and discerning to spiritual realities (Isaiah 21:6-8, Isaiah 21:9).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 21:13-15 teach about offering practical help and kindness to others in times of distress?
options: Providing shelter, water, and bread to those fleeing shows biblical compassion
Refuse help to protect your resources
Only help those who can repay you
questions.correctAnswer: Providing shelter, water, and bread to those fleeing shows biblical compassion
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:13-15 recounts how inhabitants of Arabia provided water and bread to fugitives, modeling the Christian call to practical kindness and generosity (Isaiah 21:13-15, Isaiah 21:14).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 21:1 refers to the 'burden of the __________ of the sea,' symbolizing a difficult and fearful situation.
questions.correctAnswer: desert
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:1 begins with 'The burden of the desert of the sea,' referring to a harsh and terrible land, symbolizing trials and challenges believers face.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 21:17 encourage believers to maintain integrity and trust in God's promises despite diminishing strength or resources?
options: God’s word assures that even when strength fades, His promise stands
questions.correctAnswer: God’s word assures that even when strength fades, His promise stands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:17 speaks of the diminishing might of Kedar’s archers but emphasizes that the LORD God of Israel has spoken it, encouraging trust in God's unchanging promises despite human weakness (Isaiah 21:17, Isaiah 21:16).

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 21.

questions.question: In Isaiah 21:2, which two nations are called upon to take action against the enemy?
questions.correctAnswer: Elam and Media
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:2 specifically instructs Elam to go up and Media to besiege, indicating their roles in the prophecy against the treacherous dealer.

questions.question: Isaiah 21:3 uses the imagery of a woman in labor to describe the prophet's emotional state. What literary device is primarily employed here?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The verse says 'as the pangs of a woman that travaileth,' which is a simile comparing the prophet's pain to childbirth pangs (Isaiah 21:3).

questions.question: What command does the LORD give regarding the watchman in Isaiah 21:6?
options: Go, set a watchman to declare what he sees
Call for a fast and prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Go, set a watchman to declare what he sees
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:6 explicitly states the Lord's command to set a watchman to observe and declare what he sees.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 21:9, what significant event does the watchman announce?
options: Babylon has fallen and its idols are broken
The armies of Media are advancing
The deserts are filled with whirlwinds
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon has fallen and its idols are broken
questions.explanation: Verse 9 clearly states the watchman announces 'Babylon is fallen, is fallen; and all the graven images of her gods he hath broken unto the ground.'

questions.question: The repeated phrase 'Watchman, what of the night?' appears in which verse, indicating a sense of anxious inquiry?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah 21:11
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 21:11, the burden of Dumah includes the call to the watchman asking anxiously about the night.

questions.question: What is the watchman's cryptic answer in Isaiah 21:12 regarding the coming of morning and night?
options: The morning cometh, and also the night
The night shall be dark and full of fear
The dawn will bring peace to the land
The shadows will lengthen and consume all
questions.correctAnswer: The morning cometh, and also the night
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:12 records the watchman's reply: 'The morning cometh, and also the night,' indicating a cycle of uncertainty and warning.

questions.question: Isaiah 21:14 describes the inhabitants of Tema providing what to the thirsty and fleeing?
questions.correctAnswer: Water and bread
questions.explanation: Verse 14 states the inhabitants of Tema brought water to him that was thirsty and prevented with bread him that fled.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'the burden of the desert of the sea' in Isaiah 21:1 likely symbolize in the context of ancient Near Eastern geography and prophecy?
options: A prophetic oracle concerning a coastal desert region
A metaphor for internal spiritual struggle
A description of the Nile Delta
questions.correctAnswer: A prophetic oracle concerning a coastal desert region
questions.explanation: The 'desert of the sea' likely refers to a wilderness region near the sea, such as the Arabian desert near the Persian Gulf, indicating a prophetic message about that area (Isaiah 21:1).

questions.question: What is the significance of the chariot imagery in Isaiah 21:7 and 21:9, particularly the mention of different types of chariots and horsemen?
options: It portrays the military forces and the swift approach of invading armies
It symbolizes the journey of the soul
It represents ancient modes of transportation for merchants
It is a metaphor for social status
questions.correctAnswer: It portrays the military forces and the swift approach of invading armies
questions.explanation: The description of chariots and horsemen in verses 7 and 9 serves as a military image forecasting imminent attack and conquest (Isaiah 21:7, 21:9).

questions.question: In Isaiah 21:5, the prophet commands "Prepare the table, watch in the watchtower, eat, drink: arise, ye princes, and anoint the shield." What is the literary function of this verse within the chapter?
options: A call to readiness and vigilance before impending conflict
An invitation to a celebratory feast
A description of a ritual cleansing
questions.correctAnswer: A call to readiness and vigilance before impending conflict
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:5 uses imperative commands to urge preparation and alertness, reflecting the imminent threat and need for defense.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 21:16-17, what does the Lord declare will happen to the glory and archers of Kedar within a year?
options: They shall fail and be diminished
They shall form a new alliance
questions.correctAnswer: They shall fail and be diminished
questions.explanation: Verses 16 and 17 prophesy the downfall of Kedar's glory and the diminishing of its archers as declared by the Lord.

questions.question: The term 'Dumah' in Isaiah 21:11 is connected historically and geographically with which region or people?
questions.correctAnswer: Seir and the Edomites
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:11 refers to Dumah calling out from Seir, a region associated with the Edomites, indicating a burden against Edom.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 21:4 describes the prophet's night of pleasure turning into fear.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:4 states, 'the night of my pleasure hath he turned into fear unto me,' confirming the transformation of joy into fear.

questions.question: Which theme running through Isaiah 21 is reflected in the breaking of the graven images of Babylon's gods as mentioned in Isaiah 21:9?
options: The judgment against idolatry and false gods
The restoration of Israel's temple worship
The coming of a peaceful era
questions.correctAnswer: The judgment against idolatry and false gods
questions.explanation: The breaking of Babylon's idols in verse 9 symbolizes divine judgment against idolatry, a key prophetic theme.

questions.question: In the context of Isaiah 21, what does the repeated use of the word 'burden' (Hebrew: massa) signify in prophetic literature?
options: A heavy oracle or message of judgment
A physical load carried by the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: A heavy oracle or message of judgment
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'massa' used in Isaiah 21 denotes a burden or oracle, typically a serious prophetic message often concerning judgment (Isaiah 21:1, 21:11, 21:13).

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is described as the source of the burden in Isaiah 21?
questions.correctAnswer: The desert of the sea
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:1 states the burden is of the desert of the sea, indicating a harsh, wilderness origin. This symbolizes desolation and judgment consistent with imagery in Isaiah 35:1 and Revelation 17:3, where wilderness and desolation are associated with God’s judgment.

questions.question: Which two nations are commanded to act in verse 2?
questions.correctAnswer: Elam and Media
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:2 commands Elam and Media to besiege, highlighting God's sovereign use of nations to fulfill His judgment (cf. Jeremiah 25:25, Daniel 8:20-21, and Isaiah 13:17). This reflects God's control over history and nations.

questions.question: What physical reaction does the prophet have upon receiving the grievous vision?
options: Pangs as of a woman in labor
questions.correctAnswer: Pangs as of a woman in labor
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:3 describes pain like a woman in labor, expressing the deep anguish and sorrow that comes with divine revelation of judgment. This metaphor is also used in John 16:21 and Romans 8:22 to describe suffering before redemption.

questions.question: What does the prophet say has been turned into fear?
questions.correctAnswer: The night of my pleasure
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:4 states, 'the night of my pleasure hath he turned into fear,' illustrating how God’s revelation can transform joy into dread due to impending judgment. This aligns with themes in Habakkuk 3:16 and Lamentations 3:19-20 where pleasure turns to lament.

questions.question: What preparation is instructed in verse 5?
options: Prepare the table, watch in the watchtower, eat, drink
Build a temple, pray, fast, sing
Gather the people, teach, baptize, preach
Harvest the fields, store grain, feed the poor, rejoice
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare the table, watch in the watchtower, eat, drink
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:5 commands preparation and vigilance, symbolizing readiness for coming events, a theme related to watchfulness in Matthew 24:42-44 and 1 Peter 4:7. It reflects the believer’s call to spiritual alertness.

questions.question: What role does the Lord assign in verse 6?
options: Set a watchman to declare what he sees
Send a prophet to the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Set a watchman to declare what he sees
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:6 records God's command to set a watchman, emphasizing God's sovereign oversight and prophetic warning, consistent with Ezekiel 33:7, Habakkuk 2:1, and Luke 21:36 where watchmen symbolize divine vigilance.

questions.question: What animals are mentioned pulling the chariots in verse 7?
questions.correctAnswer: Horses, asses, and camels
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:7 mentions chariots of horses, asses, and camels, depicting a diverse and possibly chaotic army, illustrating the breadth of God's judgment (cf. Exodus 14:9, 1 Kings 1:5, and Jeremiah 8:6). This diversity underscores the universal scope of divine sovereignty.

questions.question: What announcement does the watchman make in verse 9?
options: Babylon is fallen; her idols are broken
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon is fallen; her idols are broken
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:9 declares Babylon's fall and the breaking of her gods' images, signaling God's power over false gods and empires, consistent with Jeremiah 50:2, Revelation 18:2, and Daniel 5:23. It reveals God’s ultimate victory over idolatry.

questions.question: What question is repeated by the one calling from Seir in verse 11?
questions.correctAnswer: "Watchman, what of the night?"
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:11 repeats the question 'Watchman, what of the night?', symbolizing anxious anticipation and the need for prophetic insight, paralleling Habakkuk 2:1 and Luke 12:37 where watchfulness for God’s timing is emphasized.

questions.question: How does the watchman respond in verse 12?
options: "The morning cometh, and also the night: if ye will enquire, enquire ye"
"The day is bright and full of hope"
questions.correctAnswer: "The morning cometh, and also the night: if ye will enquire, enquire ye"
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:12’s response reflects the ongoing cycle of judgment and hope, a tension seen in Ecclesiastes 3:1-8 and Romans 8:22-25, emphasizing the mystery of God's timing and the call to patient faith.

questions.question: Who are the travelling companies lodging in Arabia according to verse 13?
questions.correctAnswer: Dedanim
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:13 identifies Dedanim as lodging in Arabia, indicating nomadic or trading groups affected by God’s judgment, consistent with Genesis 10:7 and Ezekiel 27:15 where Dedan is linked with Arabian tribes, illustrating God’s knowledge of all peoples.

questions.question: What provision do the inhabitants of Tema offer in verse 14?
options: Water and bread to the thirsty and fleeing
questions.correctAnswer: Water and bread to the thirsty and fleeing
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:14 notes Tema’s inhabitants providing water and bread to the fleeing, illustrating God’s compassion and provision even amid judgment, paralleling Exodus 17:6, John 4:14, and Matthew 25:35 where God’s care is evident.

questions.question: From what are the people fleeing as described in verse 15?
options: Swords, bows, and the grievousness of war
questions.correctAnswer: Swords, bows, and the grievousness of war
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:15 cites fleeing from swords, bows, and war’s severity, depicting the reality of divine judgment through conflict, consistent with Judges 7:20, Psalm 46:9, and Revelation 6:4 illustrating God’s use of war as judgment.

questions.question: What timeline does God give for the fall of Kedar’s glory in verse 16?
options: Within a year, like the years of an hireling
In seven years, like a harvest cycle
After a generation, like the lifespan of a tree
At the appointed feast of the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Within a year, like the years of an hireling
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:16 specifies the fall of Kedar’s glory within a year, reflecting God’s precise control over historical events (cf. Jeremiah 25:11, Daniel 9:27, and Hosea 6:2). It portrays the certainty and swiftness of divine judgment.

questions.question: What will happen to the archers and mighty men of Kedar according to verse 17?
options: They shall build a new city
They shall be exalted by the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be diminished
questions.explanation: Isaiah 21:17 declares that the archers and mighty men of Kedar will be diminished, showing the totality of God’s judgment (cf. Psalm 68:30, Jeremiah 49:28, and Habakkuk 1:6). This reflects God’s sovereignty over military powers.
